posts.cooked:
Hi everyone,

Our team has been facing ongoing issues with the reliability of our CAN bus network. In the past, we used 2-pin connectors, but they proved to be quite unreliable. As a temporary solution, we started soldering the wires directly, but we’ve found this makes maintenance and repairs very difficult and time-consuming.

Now, we’re planning to rebuild our CAN bus system from scratch using clean and properly routed wires. Before we do, I wanted to ask: what setups have worked well for your teams? Do you have any recommendations for connectors, wire types, or general layout practices that have helped you build a more robust CAN network?

Any insights or photos of your wiring solutions would be greatly appreciated!

Thanks in advance.

link_counts.title: What are your experiences with CAN topologies other than Daisy-chaining?

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked:
Latching connectors. Maybe specific PCBs to use as wiring hubs. Small amounts of slack at connectors. Well constrained wiring paths and secured any connectors to the bot (zip-tie, clamp, hot-glue, or custom PCB).

Our CAN reliability increased significantly in 2025 after implementing the first two of these changes and we learned the later points at high disappointment later in the 2025 season.

We did allow ourselves to have longer than specified stubs. Not quite a “star topology”, but we had several 18" stubs from the custom wiring PCBs (which were completely passive, connector-only for CAN ).

I came across this thread earlier:

How Parallel CAN Bus Saved Our 2025 Season

It made me think that a setup like this might actually be a more effective approach for us as well.

link_counts.title: How Parallel CAN Bus Saved Our 2025 Season

posts.name: Brendan Simons, 5406
posts.cooked:
These have worked extremely reliably for us:

Kalolary Low Voltage Wire Connectors, 20 Pack Wire Connector 2 Pin 2 Way I Tap, Quick Solderless Universal Compact Wire Splice Connection Self-Stripping, Fits 20-24 AWG - Amazon.com

$15.49

But in general, CAN wire is a risky mix of vulnerable and critically important.     Spend a lot of time thinking about how to run it so that it won’t get strained or abraded.

posts.cooked: in the grand scheme of things what connector you use really doesn’t matter as long as its one that your team can make confidently. my alum team ran powerpoles for a season just because we used them so much already and it worked fine, choose the connector that your team makes best

posts.name: Brendan Simons, 5406
posts.cooked:
Great!  Here’s some advice from experience:

Make sure the wires are aligned properly inside the IDC “knives” before closing the housing, or else they won’t make a good connection

The housing takes a lot of force to close and pierce the wire insulation.  We often use channel-lock pliers for this job.  They have to “click” closed.

It’s difficult to reuse these connectors.  They have plastic latches which can be opened, but might break if pried open too far.  Also the cuts in the insulation left by these connectors can cause shorts.     So we tend to treat these connectors as one-time use items, and if they have to be removed, we do so by trimming off the CAN wires.

Keeping that all in mind, these connectors have really good mechanical and electrical connection strength.  We really like them.

reply_to_user.name: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons

posts.name: Tim Winters
posts.cooked:
Molex SL. You can get the crimper in first choice, and the rest of the pieces are pretty cheaply had on Digikey. Once you get practice making the connectors, they’re very easy. They’re also becoming the standard starting in 2027 (the system core has molex SL connectors built in) so you might as well adopt them now

https://www.molex.com/content/dam/molex/molex-dot-com/en_us/pdf/general/Final_Crimp_Poster_FIRST.pdf?inline

posts.name: Andy Mundell
posts.cooked:
Solder is really the answer. Maintenance and repairs may be a little more difficult, but that’s the point. It should be very difficult to sever the connection on one of the most vulnerable and essential wires on your robot.

And if you’re prepared, it doesn’t really cost you that much time when doing a repair. We keep a handful of those quick connectors ready to go. If you need to swap a motor between matches, cut the wire and use a quick connector. Then, during your next longer break, solder those wires properly.

posts.name: Brendan Simons, 5406
posts.cooked:
RicDV:

I did find these…as a possibility:

We’ve tried those once but didn’t like them.  The IDC side of those connectors is good.  The disconnectable “plug” side is less good (doesn’t latch strongly).

posts.name: Liam
posts.cooked:
These are 2491’s wiring docs. It should contain most of what you’re looking for in terms of reliability. Note that these are for us, and not complete and haven’t been throughly reviewed. If you find something feel free to write a comment, or dm me or something. But these have guided us to a flawless on field season in terms of wiring.

Achieving Wiring Credentials	3 From 0 To Competition Ready Robot	4 Basic Skills, and Best Practices	5 Crimping	6 Labeling	6 Using Regular Label Maker	6 Using The Heat Shrink Label Maker	7 Wire Management	7 Routing & Bundling	7 Zip Ties	10...
